qas.question: Did student who actively listen to classical music before studying have higher or lower scores?
What happened to the scores of students who listened to rock and roll or country?
Who experience a significant leap in their academic performance?

answers.text: students who used classical during the course of study

qas.question: What years was the study conducted in?

context: In <a4_0>1996–1997<a4_0/>, a research study was conducted on a large population of middle age students in the Cherry Creek School District in Denver, Colorado, USA. The study showed that students who actively listen to classical music before studying had <a0_0>higher<a0_0/> academic scores. The research further indicated that students who listened to the music prior to an examination also had positively elevated achievement scores. Students who listened to rock-and-roll or country had <a1_0>moderately lower<a1_0/> scores. The study further indicated that <a2_0>students who used classical during the course of study<a2_0/> had a significant leap in their academic performance; whereas, those who listened to other types of music had significantly lowered academic scores. The research was conducted over several schools within the Cherry Creek School District and was conducted through <a3_0>University of Colorado<a3_0/>. This study is reflective of several recent studies (i.e. Mike Manthei and Steve N. Kelly of the University of Nebraska at Omaha; Donald A. Hodges and Debra S. O'Connell of the University of North Carolina at Greensboro; etc.) and others who had significant results through the discourse of their work.
